candidates.title: Merging next_major_version into master
candidates.body:
This MR brings back all the commits added to `next_major_version` in the course of the last months into `master`, because I feel like ferrisetw may be ready to release a newer version.

However, we could try releasing 0.1.2 first (from the current master, e.g. to check docs.rs succeeds at generating its doc)

candidates.title: Check property flags
candidates.body:
This depends on #75 .

This improves the `// Fixme: Check flags to see which values to get for the in_type`.
We're now checking an properly returning an error in case we do not support a property.

That's better than the current situation, but we could one day implement missing property types (that's #76)

candidates.title: Using the log crate rather than bare println/eprintln
candidates.body: Because using `println` and `eprintln` in a library crate is not a very good practise. `log` gives more control to the user binary

candidates.title: Upgraded dependencies
candidates.body: This depends on #63 that must be merged first

candidates.title: Stronger types
candidates.body:
This PR depends on #63 that must be merged first

This uses more strongly-typed data

candidates.title: Integration tests
candidates.body:
This adds integration tests for user trace for kernel trace.

Note that they sometimes crash. This is because of #45 , and this will be fixed in an upcoming MR

candidates.title: Reviewed parser structs
candidates.body:
**This depends on #36, that must be merged first.**

This PR changes the way `Parser`s work and own their data.
* This adds compiler safety guarantees (safe wrappers, alignment of allocated data)
* This improves the API (preferring an `std::iter::Iterator` over a getter with explicit indices, that must be bound-checked)
* This improves performance by:
    * efficiently caching "constant" data (i.e. that does not depend on a given `EVENT_RECORD`), so that it can be reused over various `EVENT_RECORD`s.
    * avoiding cloning some structures
* This adds a "Property not found" error, and fixes #38 (I was too lazy to extract this commit outside of this MR, as it would quickly conflict with other branches)
* This is one step towards a better multi-threading capability of this crate, by removing some `&mut`s and introducing interior mutability

It is probably easier to review this PR commit-by-commit.

Also refs #18 and #25

candidates.title: Windows rs upgrade
candidates.body:
Hello, thanks for ferrisetw.

I've been experimenting with it for a few days now, and I'd like to extend and improve it (expect other merge requests soon :D ). To start with, I'm upgrading to a newer version of `windows-rs`. (tests are still passing of course. We may want to enable Github Actions on that repo though).

I've split into several commits for better review-ability, but only the last one actually compiles, so you'd probably want to squash them when merging.

candidates.title: Allow cross-compilation with msvc-wine
candidates.body: Using the full windows crate as a build-dependencies makes it impossible to cross-compile ferrisetw from linux to windows, as the windows crate tries to link on kernel32.dll and other similar libs that don't exist on linux. By instead only relying on `windows_macros` in the build script, we can avoid this problem.

candidates.title: Make KernelProviders proper const, no lazy_static
candidates.body: lazy_static makes for some fairly messy documentation as it generates custom types and other noisy content. It's also fairly unnecessary: we can totally build KernelProviders in pure const fn simply by taking the guid directly as argument. Those GUIDS themselves can be built in pure const fn through from_values, at a small ergonomics cost.

candidates.title: Fix ‘rip-off’ typo
candidates.body:
‘rip off’ is a phrasal verb, ‘rip-off’ is a noun.  Similarly to how
‘set up’ is a phrasal verb and ‘setup’ is sa noun.

However, we could try releasing 0.1.2 first (from the current master, e.g. to check docs.rs succeeds at generating its doc)
